Comments.Name: If you have impaired kidney function, an ACE inhibitor may not be a good option for you.

Hypoglycemia is low blood sugar (glucose). It usually causes hunger and general weakness. It may also cause confusion, anxiety, tremor, sweating, or palpitations. People may have nervous system symptoms or behavior changes. If you have diabetes, hypoglycemia is often may be caused by too much insulin or other diabetes medications, not eating enough carbohydrate, or exercising more than usual. People are not always aware that their blood sugar is low.

Most people with diabetes should have an A1C goal of 7% or below. This reflects an average (not fasting) blood glucose of around 150 to 160 mg/dL. Talk to your doctor about your A1C target goal. Together you can weigh your risk of diabetes complications and low blood sugar levels with the benefits of keeping blood sugar levels in range.

Most people with diabetes should try to keep their A1C below 7%. This lowers the risk of complications, such as damage to your eyes, kidneys, heart, nerves, and blood vessels. Keeping your average blood sugar level at 150 to 160 mg/dL should keep your A1C below 7%. Your doctor will help you set an A1C target that is right for you.
SGLT2 inhibitors may not be good options for you. It is not known if they are safe for pregnant women.

GFR tells you and your doctor how well your kidneys are removing waste from your blood. GFR is based on blood levels of the muscle enzyme creatinine. If your urinary albumin is high or your GFR is low, your doctor may refer you to a kidney specialist.

Insulin is a hormone produced in the pancreas. It is needed to move glucose, a source of energy, from the bloodstream into cells throughout the body. People with type 2 diabetes have developed a resistance to insulin. Some people with type 2 diabetes eventually need insulin therapy to control their blood sugar.
You should not take an SGLT2 inhibitor if you are breastfeeding.

Women with diabetes who are pregnant or planning to become pregnant may need to have A1C measured frequently. Ideally, A1C should be kept below 6% as long as low blood sugar levels can also be avoided.
Low blood glucose impairs the ability to drive safely. It also can affect your judgment about whether it's safe to continue driving.

Lower the total carbohydrates in your diet to reduce blood sugar levels. Non-starchy vegetables, fruits, whole grains, dairy products, and legumes (such as peas, beans, and lentils) should be your main sources of carbohydrates. High fiber foods have been shown to reduce the risk of type 2 diabetes and reduce mortality in people who already have diabetes. Limit or avoid drinks sweetened with any type of sugar.

Combining a GLP-1 receptor agonist with basal insulin has been reported to improve glucose control over insulin alone without increasing the risk of hypoglycemia (low blood sugar). People on this combination also tend to lose weight.

GLP-1 receptor agonists may be prescribed alone or in combination with other diabetes drugs. Single-injector products are available that combine insulin degludec with liraglutide (Xultophy) and insulin glargine with lixisenatide (Soliqua).

If you take insulin you should consider checking your blood glucose often. This may include before meals and snacks, occasionally after meals, at bedtime, before exercising, before dangerous tasks, such as driving, and whenever you suspect that your blood glucose might be low. After your low blood glucose is treated, continue your monitoring until your glucose is normal.
If you have impaired liver function, alogliptin may not be a good option for you.
Supplements and herbal products are not regulated by the FDA for safety or effectiveness. They may cause side effects, interact with other drugs you are taking, or contain harmful ingredients.
Cholesterol is a waxy, fat-like substance. It is an important building block of cells in your body. Cholesterol is carried in the bloodstream in lipoproteins.

Self-monitoring your blood glucose may help you improve your diet and avoid low blood sugar and help your doctor decide the best medications and dosages for you. In self-monitoring, a drop of blood is placed on a test strip and inserted into a meter that calculates your glucose level. Its effectiveness depends on device accuracy, proper technique, and taking action based on the results. Not everyone needs to self-monitor, so ask your doctor if it's right for you.

The FDA has warned that SGLT2 inhibitors may lead to ketoacidosis, a serious condition in which there is too much acid in the blood. There is also an increased risk of low blood sugar when taking some SGLT2 inhibitors with medicines that are known to cause hypoglycemia.

Diabetes increases the risk for complications from other diseases. Vaccines can protect you against some of those diseases, or keep your illness milder if you do contract the disease. Talk with your doctor about which vaccinations are best for you. The American Diabetes Association recommends a number of vaccines for people with diabetes:
Gliptins may not be good options for you. It is not known if they are safe for pregnant women.

Sometimes people take less insulin than prescribed because they are worried about gaining weight or about having symptoms of hypoglycemia (blood sugar that is too low). Or they may feel anxious about having diabetes or have other life stresses. But you should know that people who do not take their insulin as prescribed have higher rates of diabetes complications and a higher risk of early death.

Wear socks and shoes at all times, especially when walking on hot pavement or at the beach, even when swimming. Before you put your shoes on, check inside them for rough areas or any objects that should not be in them.
--- Slowly increase the amount of time you exercise before you increase the intensity.
If you are taking insulin, rosiglitazone can lead to side effects and should be avoided. Pioglitazone also may not be a good option for you.

A lower A1C goal may be achievable for those with a long life expectancy, no cardiovascular disease, and certain medication regimens that carry little risk of low blood sugar. A higher A1C goal ay be appropriate for those with a history of severe low blood glucose, disease complications, limited life expectancy, or long-term diabetes that does not respond well to treatment.
SGLT2 inhibitors have been reported to reduce mortality risk in people with cardiovascular disease and poorly controlled type 2 diabetes.
Liraglutide has been reported to reduce mortality risk in people with cardiovascular disease and poorly controlled type 2 diabetes.
If you are taking cimetidine, metformin may not be a good option for you.
If you are taking conivaptan, saxagliptin can lead to side effects and should be avoided.
You should not take an ARB if you are breastfeeding.
If you are taking an angiotensin II receptor antagonist, ACE inhibitors can lead to side effects and should be avoided.

The type of fat you eat is more important than how much fat you eat. Polyunsaturated and monounsaturated fats (from fatty fish and most plant based oils, for example) are better for you than saturated and trans fats (from butter, fatty meats, and many bakery items, for example).
If you are taking aliskiren, ARBs can lead to side effects and should be avoided.
If you have kidney disease, an ARB may not be a good option for you.
If you have cardiovascular disease, bromocriptine may not be a good option for you.

If you have severe kidney impairment or end-stage renal disease (ESRD), you should not take an SGLT2 inhibitor. If you have mild kidney disease, your doctor should monitor your kidney function and potassium levels while you are taking a SGLT2 inhibitor.
Vigorous aerobic or resistance exercise can trigger eye problems, such as vitreous hemorrhage or retinal detachment, in people with proliferative or severe nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy.
Clopidogrel (75 mg a day) is sometimes prescribed in place of aspirin for people who have an allergic reaction to aspirin.

Exercise doesn't have to take place in a gym. It can be as easy as walking the dog, walking or jogging during your lunch hour, biking to work, parking farther away from a destination, taking the stairs instead of the escalator or elevator, playing a game of tag with your kids, or doing yard work. Other aerobic activities include dancing, swimming, and hiking. Any activity that you perform for a sustained period and that makes your heart beat faster is likely to be aerobic.

The hormone insulin allows cells to absorb the sugar (glucose) from the bloodstream and use it for fuel. It is produced by the pancreas and is necessary for life. People with type 1 diabetes produce no insulin and must inject or inhale insulin on a regular schedule or use an insulin pump.

If you have any of these warning signs, get medical help right away. Some doctors recommend that you should check your urine for ketones whenever your blood sugar level is above 240 mg/dL. Keep a urine test kit with you. Talk to your doctor about managing high ketones in the urine.
--- Wear proper clothing, shoes, and protective gear. Comfort and safety are important.
If you have had melanoma, bromocriptine may not be a good option for you.

Side effects may include low blood pressure, dehydration, flu-like symptoms, nose and throat irritation, increased urination, and high cholesterol. Some people have an allergic reaction. SGLT2 inhibitors may increase your risk of genital and urinary tract infections and bone fractures.
--- Look for health and fitness classes in your community.
--- Drink water to stay hydrated.

Signs and symptoms of hypoglycemia happen suddenly. You may experience headache, hunger, nausea, shakiness, sweating, chills, clamminess, weakness, or fatigue. You may feel your heart racing or pounding, or notice dizziness, blurry vision, or a tingling or burning in your lips or tongue. Hypoglycemia can affect your mental functioning. You may suddenly feel uncoordinated, sleepy, irritable, impatient, nervous, anxious, confused, angry, or sad.

Your doctor may also recommend a continuous glucose monitoring device. These devices may help people on insulin therapy, people with type 2 diabetes that are taking medications that have a risk of low blood sugar, and people who find it difficult to recognize when blood sugar is low. Both types of home monitoring of blood sugar can help you achieve your blood sugar targets. They can also help guide nutrition and activity decisions and prevent extremes of blood sugar.

SGLT2 (sodium-dependent glucose co-transporter 2) inhibitors lower blood sugar by helping the kidneys remove it from the body in the urine. They are taken by mouth. SGLT2 inhibitors include canagliflozin (Invokana), dapagliflozin (Farxiga), and empagliflozin (Jardiance). Invokamet, Xigduo XR, and Synjardy are combinations with metformin. Glyxambi combines empagliflozin and linagliptin.
If you are taking a gliptin, an ACE inhibitor may not be a good option for you.
If you have impaired kidney function, aspirin may not be a good option for you.
--- Worsening of diabetic eye and kidney problems
If you are taking a strong CYP3A4 enzyme inhibitor, bromocriptine can lead to side effects and should be avoided.
If you are taking a typical antipsychotic, bromocriptine can lead to side effects and should be avoided.
If you have trouble with glucose control, take the following steps before driving.
Inhaled insulin may not be a good option for you. It is not known if it is safe for pregnant women.

For people who use continuous monitoring devices, the results are reported as time-in-range (TIR), or how often your blood sugar level is where it should be. The goal is to have your blood sugar levels in range (63 ? 140 mg/dL) more than 70% of the time and to be below range no more often than 4% of the time.

People who smoke are more likely to develop type 2 diabetes. This is because the nicotine and other chemicals in cigarettes damage your cells so they don't respond as well to insulin. If you smoke, you are also more prone to belly fat which is another risk factor for type 2 diabetes. Smokers are 30% to 40% more likely than non-smokers to get type 2 diabetes.

Diabetes is a disease in which the body is unable to make enough insulin or cannot use insulin the way it should. Insulin is a hormone that is created by your pancreas, an organ located in your abdomen. Insulin turns glucose (blood sugar) into energy.

Gliptins, also called DPP-4 inhibitors, raise the level of the hormone incretin. This increases insulin and lowers glucagon. The overall effect is that more glucose is absorbed by cells and less glucose is produced in the liver. Gliptins are taken by mouth. They may be prescribed alone or in combination with other diabetes drugs.

Signs and symptoms of diabetes can include dry mouth, increased thirst, the need to urinate often, constant hunger, weight loss, and fatigue. Other symptoms include sores that heal slowly, blurred vision, a loss of feeling or tingling in the feet, and dry, itchy skin. Some people with diabetes experience one or more of these, but others have none.

There are three main types of diabetes: type 1, type 2, and gestational. Type 1, usually diagnosed in younger people, occurs when the body's immune system destroys beta cells in the pancreas. These are the cells that produce insulin. People with type 1 diabetes make little or no insulin and need regular insulin injections.
--- COVID-19
Here are some strategies for making meals and snacks healthful and nutritious.

Type 2 diabetes, the most common type, can occur at any age. It develops when fat, muscle, and liver cells gradually stop responding to insulin. The pancreas increases its output of insulin, but the response from the cells continues to fall. Eventually, the pancreas cannot produce enough insulin to cope with glucose spikes after meals. Obesity and lack of exercise increase the risk for type 2 diabetes.

Coronavirus 2019 (COVID-19) is a disease that mainly affects the lungs and breathing. The CDC recommends COVID-19 vaccination for adolescents and adults who are at risk of COVID-19 infection. People with diabetes type1 or type 2 are at greater risk of complications and severe disease with COVID-19. Check with your doctor or local health department to see where you can receive the vaccine.

Gestational diabetes is a type that sometimes occurs during the later stages of pregnancy. It happens when hormones produced by the placenta, the sac around the fetus, interfere with the normal action of insulin. Gestational diabetes usually lasts only as long as the pregnancy, but women who have had it are at risk for type 2 diabetes later in life.

It's a good idea to keep track of how you feel when your sugar is low. Talk to your doctor about when and how best to treat your hypoglycemia. Everyone is different, but some strategies are listed below.

Other drugs for type 2 diabetes include alpha-glucosidase inhibitors, glinides, colesevelam, bromocriptine, and pramlintide. Doctors do not usually recommend these drugs first because they may not work as well, they need to be taken more often, they have more side effects, and they may cost more than others.

The overall goal of dietary management of your diabetes is to support healthy eating over your lifetime. Focus on foods that are rich in nutrients. Choose portion sizes that allow you to achieve and maintain a healthy weight, blood sugar, blood pressure, and lipid targets. Healthy eating can delay or prevent the complications of diabetes.

If you are overweight, even a small amount of weight loss can improve your health and your A1C levels. Besides diabetes, health conditions associated with being overweight include cholesterol problems, high blood pressure, some types of cancer, fatty liver disease, osteoarthritis, sleep apnea, and acid reflux disease. When you are ready to lose weight, talk to your doctor for support and to learn more about weight loss options. A 5% weight loss is a good goal to start with.

A study of 15,480 diabetic men and women without cardiovascular disease, found that aspirin reduced the risk of serious heart and blood vessel events, such as heart attacks and strokes, by about 12%. The risk of bleeding in the aspirin group was 4.1% compared to 3.2% in the control group. Most of the bleeding was in the stomach and intestines.

Some people with diabetes can lose weight with lifestyle changes like healthy eating and physical activity. Behavioral therapy helps many people stay on track when trying to lose weight. Some medications for diabetes promote weight loss as well. Weight-loss surgery may be recommended for people whose BMI is 40 or higher, and for people with a high BMI who can't control their diabetes with drug treatments.
--- Eat more fruits, vegetables, and whole grains.

People with diabetes and protein in their urine can benefit from taking an ACE inhibitor (angiotensin-converting-enzyme inhibitor) or an ARB (angiotensin receptor blocker). Either drug is recommended for people with a urinary albumin excretion rate of 30 mg per day or above. ACE inhibitors and ARBs are not recommended for people with normal blood pressure and kidney function measures. You should not take both an ACE inhibitor and an ARB.
--- Switch to low-fat or fat-free milk and dairy products (cheese, yogurt).

Physical activity is one of the most important ingredients of good health. Besides improving overall fitness, strength, and flexibility, regular exercise reduces the risks for many medical problems, such as high blood pressure, heart disease, stroke, and depression. It also helps to improve cholesterol, control weight, and reduce stress. As people age, physical fitness makes it easier to perform everyday tasks.
If you are taking Viekira, metformin may not be a good option for you.
If you are taking conivaptan, bromocriptine can lead to side effects and should be avoided.

You should have a foot exam at least once a year to avoid problems that could lead to a foot ulcer or amputation. If you have already had a foot ulcer or amputation, or you have a foot deformity, loss of feeling in your feet, or artery disease in your feet or legs, you should have a foot exam at every doctor visit.
--- Keep a blood glucose meter and a snack in the vehicle. A snack should be a rapid-acting source of sugar, such as juice, a regular soft drink (not diet soda), hard candy, or dextrose tablets.
If you are taking an ACE inhibitor, ARBs may not be good options for you.
If you are taking an ACE inhibitor, gliptins may not be good options for you.
--- Include lean meats, poultry (chicken, turkey), seafood, beans, eggs, and nuts in your diet.
If you are taking fusidic acid, bromocriptine can lead to side effects and should be avoided.
If you are taking temsirolimus, an ACE inhibitor may not be a good option for you.
--- Avoid processed foods, high-fat foods, salty foods, and foods with added sugar.

--- Never start a drive if you have symptoms of hypoglycemia (low blood sugar). Those may include confusion, anxiety, tremor, sweating, or palpitations. If you have symptoms of hypoglycemia, eat or drink enough carbohydrate to bring your blood sugar level back up. If you have a blood glucose meter, check your blood sugar level before getting behind the wheel.
When you begin an exercise program, some things will greatly improve your success.

Most people start treatment with metformin. Medical guidelines state that if you don't reach your A1C target with metformin or another drug after about 3 months, you may need to add another type of drug to your treatment plan. If you don't reach your A1C target with 2 drugs, you may need to add a third drug. Some people need insulin therapy to reach their A1C target. These guidelines also say that each drug you add may lower your A1C by about 1%.
--- Invite a friend to join you. Working out with a friend can keep you on track and make exercise more enjoyable.
--- Eat regular meals, including breakfast.
--- Control portion sizes.

Glinides help the beta cells in the pancreas produce insulin. Glinides available in the US include nateglinide (Starlix) and repaglinide (Prandin). These drugs are taken by mouth. They may be prescribed alone or in combination with other diabetes drugs. A product combining repaglinide with metformin (Prandimet) is also available.
--- Remember that fat-free does not mean calorie-free.
--- pneumococcus
Be physically active for at least 30 minutes most days of the week. Here are some strategies to add physical activity to your day.
--- Go for a walk, ride a bike, or swim.
If you are taking dabrafenib, glitazones can lead to side effects and should be avoided.

Low blood sugar is the most common side effect of insulin. It is more common in people who have irregular eating patterns, those who exercise without adjusting their food intake or insulin dosage, and people being treated with intensive insulin therapy.
If you are taking topiramate, metformin may not be a good option for you.
--- Ride a stationary bike. Walk or jog on a treadmill.
If you are taking eplerenone, an ACE inhibitor may not be a good option for you.
--- Take an exercise class.
If you are taking a QTc interval prolonging medication, metformin can lead to serious side effects
If you are taking idelalisib, bromocriptine can lead to side effects and should be avoided.

The most common side effects of inhaled insulin are headache, cough, and throat pain or irritation. Inhaled insulin may also cause bronchospasm (narrowing of air passages in the lungs), low potassium levels in the blood, and allergic reactions, which can be severe.
--- hepatitis B
Angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs) block the effects of the hormone angiotensin. They help to lower blood pressure and limit the retention of salt and water by the kidneys.
If you are taking lorcaserin, bromocriptine can lead to side effects and should be avoided.
--- If you find it hard to add exercise to your day, try shorter sessions. For example, exercise for 15 minutes twice a day instead of half an hour once a day.

After a transplant, your blood sugar control should improve, and you should need less insulin. Your risk of hypoglycemia (very low blood sugar) should also go down. As with any transplant, there is a risk of bleeding or blood clots after the procedure. There is also a chance that the new islet cells will not function well. Medications required to prevent rejection can also cause side effects.

Diabetes requires lifelong, day-to-day management. Over time, poor glucose control can affect your heart, eyes, kidneys, nerves, and digestive system. To reduce the risk of other diseases, it is important to carefully manage your blood glucose level.

Rapid-acting forms of insulin include lispro (Humalog, Admelog), aspart (Novolog, Fiasp), and glulisine (Apidra). They start working in about 15 minutes. These drugs reach their peak effect in about 1 to 2 hours, and the effects last for 2 to 4 hours.

Bromocriptine is a drug that was developed to treat Parkinson's disease, acromegaly, and symptoms caused by high levels of the hormone prolactin. A rapid-release form of bromocriptine (Cycloset) is also approved for treating type 2 diabetes. It is an option to add as a second or third drug when treatment targets have not been met.

Short-acting or regular insulin (Humulin R, Novolin R, Velosulin R) starts working in about 30 to 60 minutes. It reaches peak effect in about 2 to 3 hours, and its effects last about 3 to 6 hours. Intermediate-acting or NPH insulin (Humulin N, Novolin N, ReliOn) starts working in 2 to 4 hours. It reaches peak effect in 8 to 16 hours, and the effects last for 12 to 18 hours.

Normally, your body turns food into glucose, and the glucose is carried in your bloodstream to cells all around your body. Insulin is also released into your bloodstream, where it helps the glucose get from the blood into the cells. When your body does not make enough insulin or cannot use it properly, too much glucose stays in your blood.
If you are taking pregabalin, an ACE inhibitor may not be a good option for you.
If you have liver function impairment, a glinide may not be a good option for you.
If you are taking gold sodium thiomalate, an ACE inhibitor may not be a good option for you.

Diabetes is managed with oral medications or insulin therapy, continual and careful monitoring of blood glucose, particularly if you're on insulin, and a healthy lifestyle. It is also important to manage your blood pressure, cholesterol, and triglyceride levels, and to maintain good oral hygiene, foot care, and eye care.
If you have peptic ulcer, bromocriptine may not be a good option for you.
--- flu (influenza)
If you are taking pimozide, glyburide can lead to side effects and should be avoided.
If you are taking an angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor, aspirin may not be a good option for you.

Several GLP-1 receptor agonists are recommended for people with type 2 diabetes who are looking to lose weight and safely control their blood sugar. All GLP-1 receptor agonists can result in weight loss. Some are more effective in reducing A1C.
--- shingles

Alcohol should be limited to 1 drink a day for women and 2 drinks a day for men. 1 drink is 12 ounces of beer, 5 ounces of wine, or 1.5 ounces of distilled spirits. Alcohol can affect blood sugar levels. If you drink alcohol, monitor blood sugar frequently afterward.
If you have impaired kidney function, inhaled insulin may not be a good option for you.
If you have impaired liver function, inhaled insulin may not be a good option for you.
If you have chronic lung disease, such as asthma or COPD, you should not use inhaled insulin.

Most people use needles to inject insulin. Most types of needles are coated to cut down on any pain while you are injecting. Insulin pens have fine, short needles that inject insulin from prefilled cartridges with a plunger that you push. Insulin jet injectors use high-pressure air rather than needles to inject the insulin.

An insulin pump, worn outside the body, has tubing that delivers the insulin to a catheter (a small tube) under the skin of the abdomen. The pump is programmed to deliver a steady supply of insulin, and can deliver extra insulin after meals or when blood glucose is high. The pump provides maximum control of blood glucose, which is known to reduce the rate of diabetes complications.
If you are taking a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug, aspirin may not be a good option for you.
Inhaled insulin is not recommended for people who smoke or have recently quit smoking.
If you are taking bosentan, you should not take glyburide and avoid tolbutamide if possible.
If you are taking nitroglycerin, bromocriptine can lead to side effects and should be avoided.
ACE inhibitors increase the risk of a severe allergic reaction to grass pollen allergen extract (5-grass extract).
If you are taking spironolactone, an ACE inhibitor may not be a good option for you.
If you take a sulfonylurea, you should avoid alcohol.
--- tetanus, diphtheria, pertussis (Tdap) booster

There are two main types of lipoproteins: low density lipoprotein (LDL) and high-density lipoprotein (HDL). Most of the cholesterol in the blood is in the form of LDL. LDL carries cholesterol to tissues, including the arteries. HDL takes cholesterol from tissues to the liver, which removes it from the body. Triglycerides are another type of fat, produced in the liver and found in food. All of these fatty substances are called lipids.
--- Add physical activities to your daily routine.
If you have renal artery stenosis, an ACE inhibitor may not be a good option for you.

People with diabetes often have nerve damage, especially in their hands and feet (peripheral neuropathy). This can result in weak muscles or loss of feeling, which raises the risk of injury, foot ulcers, and other problems related to physical activity.
If you are taking tedizolid, bromocriptine can lead to serious side effects.

People with type 1 diabetes should have an initial dilated and comprehensive eye exam by an ophthalmologist or optometrist within five years of the diagnosis of diabetes. If there are no problems, exams should be repeated at least every 1 to 2 years. If any exam reveals a problem, exams should be repeated at least yearly. If a problem is severe or getting worse, exams should be more frequent.

--- Stop driving immediately if you have any symptoms of low blood glucose. Measure and treat the blood glucose level, and do not continue driving until you are sure your blood glucose and mental functions are normal. This may take up to an hour.
If you have had thyroid cancer, you should not take a GLP-1 receptor agonist.

Lowering LDL is an important goal of lipid management, since a high LDL level increases the risk for heart disease. Low HDL and high triglycerides also increase the risk for heart disease, so managing these is also important.

Several sulfonylureas are available in the US. These include glimepiride (Amaryl), glipizide (Glucotrol), glyburide (DiaBeta, Glynase), acetohexamide, chlorpropamide (Diabinese), tolazamide, and tolbutamide. Some other products combine a sulfonylurea in a single pill with another diabetes drug, such as metformin.
Even if you have no pain, watch for warning signs of gum disease. See your dentist if you have any of these signs:

Brushing and flossing are important. Brush twice a day for 3 minutes each time, using a gentle scrubbing motion and short strokes. Use a soft-bristle brush with rounded ends and replace it every 3 to 4 months. Brush all the surfaces of your teeth, your gums, and the rough surface of your tongue.

Floss every day. Use a gentle sawing motion, rather than snapping, to get the floss between your teeth. Curve the floss around each tooth, scraping up and down to remove plaque. Be sure to floss the back surfaces of teeth in the back of your mouth. Rinse with water when finished.
Women who develop diabetes during pregnancy (gestational diabetes) do not appear to have an increased risk of developing retinopathy and do not need an eye exam during pregnancy.

Several gliptins are available in the US. These include alogliptin (Nesina), linagliptin (Tradjenta), saxagliptin (Onglyza), and sitagliptin (Januvia). Some other products combine a gliptin with another diabetes drug in a single pill, such as Glyxambi, Janumet, Jentadueto, Kazano, Kombiglyze XR, Oseni, and Qtern.

Many ACE inhibitors are available in the US. These include benazepril (Lotensin), captopril (Capoten), enalapril (Vasotec), fosinopril, lisinopril (Prinivil, Zestril), moexipril (Univasc), perindopril (Aceon), quinapril (Accupril), ramipril (Altace), and trandolapril (Mavik).

If you have DKA your blood glucose levels are high, usually above 250 mg/dL. You may be very thirsty and urinate more than usual. Abdominal pain, vomiting, and dehydration are common. Your heart rate and breathing is faster than usual. Without insulin, some people with DKA become lethargic and confused. Blood pressure drops. The condition can lead to coma or death.

Visit a dentist at least twice a year and be sure the dentist knows that you have diabetes. The best time for dental work is when blood sugar is in a normal range, so eat before going to the dentist. If you take insulin, try to schedule your visit for the morning, and eat a normal breakfast.

Both pregnancy itself and the tight blood glucose control needed during pregnancy make retinopathy worse. Women with pre-existing diabetes should have an eye exam before getting pregnant, or in the first trimester. Exams may need to be repeated every trimester and for 1 year after delivery. Women who develop diabetes during pregnancy (gestational diabetes) do not appear to have an increased risk of developing retinopathy and do not need an eye exam during pregnancy.
--- human papillomavirus (HPV)
If you are taking a corticosteroid, a sulfonylurea may not be a good option for you.

Regular eye exams are very important for people with diabetes. Diabetes carries a high risk of retinopathy. Retinopathy is damage to blood vessels in the retina, the part of the eye that detects light. The damage may cause no symptoms at first, but without diagnosis and treatment it can lead to blindness. Other eye problems, such as cataracts and glaucoma, also occur more often and at a younger age in people with diabetes.
Metformin may not be a good option for you. It is not known if it is safe for pregnant women.

Take your usual medications before your visit. Return to your normal meal schedule after dental work or, if needed, eat softer foods or liquids, as recommended by your dentist. Hold off on dental surgery if your blood sugar is not under good control.

Many ARBs are available in the US. These include azilsartan (Edarbi), candesartan (Atacand), eprosartan (Teveten), irbesartan (Avapro), losartan (Cozaar), olmesartan (Benicar), telmisartan (Micardis), and valsartan (Diovan).

The longer you have diabetes and the higher your blood sugar, the greater your chances of diabetic retinopathy. High blood pressure, high cholesterol, and kidney problems also raise your risk. Regular eye exams can catch retinopathy before you have vision symptoms, so you can get early treatment to prevent vision loss.

Sodium (found in salt and many processed foods) should be limited to 2,300 mg a day. This is the same recommendation for people with and without diabetes. People with high blood pressure are advised to lower their sodium intake to 1500 mg a day.

Autonomic neuropathy is a group of symptoms resulting from damage caused by high blood sugar to nerves that manage everyday bodily functions. These functions include blood pressure, heart rate, sweating, bowel and bladder emptying, and digestion.

Dry mouth can raise your risk of cavities and other problems, such as salivary gland infections. High blood sugar and some diabetes medications can cause dry mouth. To avoid dry mouth, drink more fluids, use sugar-free gum or sugar-free hard candy to keep the saliva flowing, or use saliva substitutes.

Your doctor should regularly check for symptoms of autonomic neuropathy. Some symptoms are a rapid heart rate at rest, feeling dizzy when you stand up, an increase or decrease in sweating, diarrhea, constipation, loss of bowel control, and erectile dysfunction in men.

Cardiovascular autonomic neuropathy involves nerves that control the heart, and is particularly important to screen for. People with type 2 diabetes should be screened every year beginning as soon as diabetes is diagnosed. People with type 1 diabetes should be screened every year starting 5 years after diagnosis.

In addition to getting recommended vaccines, you can cut down your risk of infections by washing your hands regularly. Clean hard surfaces that you touch often, such as doorknobs and countertops. Cough or sneeze into a tissue or into the crook of your arm. Limit your exposure to cigarette smoke and take steps to prevent or get treatment for conditions such as HIV/AIDS.

Pneumococcal infections are caused by bacteria that can lead to life-threatening infections including pneumonia, meningitis, and bacteremia (blood infection). The CDC recommends a pneumococcal vaccination for anyone with a high risk for pneumococcal disease or serious complications of infection.
If you are taking a thrombolytic drug, aspirin may not be a good option for you.
People with HHS are often lethargic or confused. Fever is common, and they may have seizures, weakness, paralysis, or vision loss. HHS sometimes results in a coma.

Gastrointestinal neuropathies involve nerves that control digestion. They may affect any part of the gastrointestinal tract. The stomach may not be able to pass food to the intestines properly. Constipation may alternate with diarrhea.

Autonomic neuropathy may involve the bladder, resulting in urinary tract infections, incontinence, or bladder enlargement. In men, autonomic neuropathy may cause erectile dysfunction or ejaculation problems. In women, it may cause loss of sexual desire, increased pain during intercourse, and poor lubrication.

Good blood sugar control can prevent or slow the development of autonomic neuropathy in people with diabetes. You can improve symptoms of autonomic neuropathy by carefully controlling your blood sugar, including avoiding large swings in it.

Diabetic retinopathy usually develops about 5 years after chronic high blood sugar develops. If you have type 1 diabetes, you should start having regular eye exams within 5 years of being diagnosed with it. People with type 2 diabetes may have had high blood sugar for years before being diagnosed. So you should start having regular eye exams as soon as you are diagnosed with type 2 diabetes.
Your healthcare provider will need to test your kidney function before starting treatment.

If you often have low blood sugar, you may need a change of medication type, dose, or timing. Talk to your doctor as soon as possible. For some people, a higher target A1C may be necessary for safety reasons. Testing your blood glucose more often can help you figure out what causes your low blood sugar, and it can help you and your doctor choose the best medication, diet, and lifestyle plan. That might include a device that monitors your blood glucose continuously.

The results in this consultation are primarily designed for adults. It is important to know that management for most health conditions is different for children than it is for adults. While some basic treatment steps may be similar, a child will often need different drugs, different dosages, or other child-specific treatment strategies. Some medical and self-care treatments should never be used to treat children.
Talk to your pediatrician or another qualified health care provider about which management options your child should try.

Talk to your doctor to see if low-dose aspirin is right for you. Aspirin is not recommended for men or women under age 50 who have no other major risk factors for cardiovascular disease. Aspirin therapy increases the risk of bleeding. This risk must be balanced with the benefit of reducing cardiovascular disease.

The exam will look for loss of feeling in your feet and signs of artery disease in your legs. Your healthcare provider will check the skin on your feet. The provider will measure feeling in your feet using a small filament, pinprick, or vibration from a tuning fork. The exam may also include tests to check your ankle reflexes and pulses in your legs and feet.

The A1C target in pregnancy is lower than for women who are not pregnant. The target reflects the changes to red blood cell turnover in pregnant women and the effects of blood sugar on the developing baby. Ideally, the A1C is less than 6% during pregnancy. The A1C may need to be measured monthly. The target may be relaxed to less than 7% to prevent excessively low blood sugar, if it occurs.
If you take metformin, you should avoid alcohol.

Many programs are available to help people learn about blood glucose awareness and driving with diabetes, including online. These programs can help you recognize, prevent, and treat blood glucose problems and avoid or manage low blood glucose when driving.
If you are taking dabrafenib, linagliptin can lead to side effects and should be avoided.

Bromocriptine has been reported to lower A1C by 0.5% to 0.7% when taken alone or with other oral diabetes drugs. It also may reduce the risk of cardiovascular disease in people with type 2 diabetes. However, it is generally less effective than other oral diabetes drugs and is prescribed considerably less often.

Side effects may include inflammation of the pancreas (pancreatitis), liver failure, and severe hypersensitivity reactions. Other side effects may include headaches, cough, inflamed throat and sinuses, upper respiratory infections, urinary tract infections, joint pain, and back pain.
Your doctor will need to test your kidney function before starting treatment. Before starting alogliptin, your liver function will also be tested.
If you have severe kidney function impairment, a glinide may not be a good option for you.

Side effects may include dizziness, weakness, headache, lazy eye, sneezing, runny or stuffy nose, postnasal drip, flu-like symptoms, very low blood pressure, loss of appetite, nausea, vomiting, and constipation. Bromocriptine can make it dangerous to drive or to operate machinery.
If you are breastfeeding, gliptins may not be a good option for you. It is not known if they can be passed into breast milk.
If you have fainted during migraine headaches, you should not take bromocriptine.
--- Focus on the exercise benefits that you value (weight loss, improved sleep, improved appearance, social engagement).
If you are taking fusidic acid, saxagliptin can lead to side effects and should be avoided.
Triglyceride levels below 150 mg/dL and an HDL above 40 mg/dL for men and above 50 mg/dL for women are desirable.
If you are taking idelalisib, saxagliptin can lead to side effects and should be avoided.

For people with type 2 diabetes, insulin therapy usually begins with injections, once a day, of a long-acting insulin added to their oral diabetes drugs. People whose A1C is 9.0% or above may need to take both long-acting and mealtime insulin. Sulfonylureas and glinides are usually stopped if a mealtime insulin is prescribed.
If you have had angioedema, you should not take an ACE inhibitor.
You should not take bromocriptine if you are breastfeeding.
If you are taking a nitrate drug, a glitazone may not be a good option for you.
Side effects may include digestive tract problems, such as stomach pain, gas, and diarrhea.
Bromocriptine may not be a good option for you. It is not known if it is safe for pregnant women.
If you are taking tizanidine, bromocriptine can lead to side effects and should be avoided.
If you are taking everolimus, an ACE inhibitor may not be a good option for you.
If you have psychosis, bromocriptine may not be a good option for you.
If you are taking a 5-HT3 antagonist, bromocriptine can lead to serious side effects.
If you have liver impairment, an ARB may not be a good option for you.

The American Diabetes Association says there is no proof that taking dietary supplements can improve diabetes. Unless you have a known deficiency, supplements are not recommended. Pregnant or breastfeeding women, older adults, and those following vegetarian or vegan diets who also have diabetes may need a multivitamin.

Most people with diabetes should have tests to check their urinary albumin and glomerular filtration rate (GFR) at least once a year. This includes people who have type 2 diabetes, and people with type 1 diabetes for at least 5 years.
If you are taking a protease inhibitor, bromocriptine can lead to side effects and should be avoided.

The safety of pneumococcal vaccination during pregnancy has not been well studied. The vaccine is not routinely recommended for pregnant women who are not at risk for pneumococcal disease. Ideally, women should be vaccinated before becoming pregnant. It is not known whether the vaccine is passed through breast milk. New mothers should discuss the pros and cons of vaccination with a healthcare provider.
If you are taking a triptan, bromocriptine can lead to side effects and should be avoided.

Gestational diabetes increases the risk of having a very large baby. These babies have a higher risk of medical problems at birth (such as breathing problems, low blood sugar) and as adults (obesity, type 2 diabetes). A large baby also increases your risk of needing a Cesarean section. But, because it affects the baby later in pregnancy, gestational diabetes does not cause the types of birth defects sometimes seen in babies of women with pre-existing diabetes.
If you have impaired liver function, an ACE inhibitor may not be a good option for you.

The hepatitis B virus (HBV) attacks the liver and causes an inflammation called hepatitis. It can cause a life-long infection. HBV is spread through contact with blood or body fluids (such as semen or vaginal secretions) of an infected person.
If you take bromocriptine, you should avoid alcohol.

Side effects may include heartburn, abdominal pain or cramps, nausea, indigestion, loss of appetite, vomiting, constipation, diarrhea, and gas. Aspirin may also cause depression, headaches, weakness, ringing in the ears, itching, rashes, changes in blood pressure, and swelling in the hands or feet. Aspirin increases the risk of bleeding, ulceration, and perforation of the stomach or intestines, blood clots, heart attack, and stroke, which can be fatal.
You should not take acarbose if you are breastfeeding.
If you are taking linezolid, bromocriptine can lead to serious side effects.
If you have diabetic gastropathy, you should not take pramlintide.
If you are taking dabigatran, aspirin may not be a good option for you.
If you are taking metaxalone, bromocriptine can lead to serious side effects.
If you are pregnant, you should not take an ACE inhibitor.
If you are taking metoclopramide, bromocriptine can lead to serious side effects.
If you have inflammatory bowel disease, you should not take an alpha-glucosidase inhibitor.
If you are taking gemfibrozil, you should not take repaglinide .
If you are taking an opioid, bromocriptine can lead to serious side effects.

Most people with disabilities or long-term medical conditions, such as heart disease, obesity, or diabetes, can start a moderate exercise program. But it is a good idea to talk to your doctor first. Your doctor can help you choose activities that are right for you.
If you are taking bupropion, bromocriptine may not be a good option for you.
If you are taking deoxycholic acid, aspirin may not be a good option for you.
If you are taking a factor Xa inhibitor, aspirin may not be a good option for you.
If you have had pancreatitis, gliptins may not be good options for you.
Metformin can cause a buildup of lactic acid in the blood (lactic acidosis) if there is kidney impairment. If you have abnormally high serum creatinine, you should not take metformin.
Your doctor will need to test your kidney function before starting treatment.
All diabetes-related medication, foods and liquids, equipment, and supplies must be declared, but can be taken past airport security after inspection. This includes the following:
--- Water, juice, or liquid nutrition or gels, even if over 3.4 ounces each
--- Insulin vials, jet injectors, EpiPens, infusers, and preloaded syringes
If you are pregnant, you should not take an ARB.
If you are taking methylphenidate, bromocriptine may not be a good option for you.

The CDC recommends that only adults at high risk for infection should get a hepatitis B vaccination. This includes people with diabetes, liver disease, HIV infection, and on kidney dialysis. Other high risks include travel to developing countries, contact with a person with hepatitis B, injection drug use, and jobs that involve contact with human blood, such as healthcare work.
If you are taking a serotonin reuptake inhibitor, bromocriptine may not be a good option for you.
--- Glucagon emergency kit
If you have renal artery stenosis, an ARB may not be a good option for you.
--- Unused syringes if accompanied by insulin or other injectable medication

You should not get the hepatitis B vaccine if you have had an allergic reaction to a previous dose of hepatitis B vaccine or if you are allergic to yeast. (Hepatitis B vaccine is developed in baker's yeast.)

Side effects may include low blood sugar, headache, acid reflux, indigestion, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, constipation, and skin problems at the injection site. Some people have had severe allergic reactions, pancreatitis, or gallstones. Suicidal thoughts have occurred in some people taking liraglutide. GLP-1 receptor agonists have caused thyroid cancer in animals.
Drug therapy usually includes an ACE inhibitor or angiotensin receptor blocker (ARB), but not both. Most people will need to take more than one drug to reach blood pressure targets.
Side effects may include fatigue, dizziness, cough, and upper respiratory tract infections.
--- Sharps or similar disposal containers, which may contain used syringes
--- Lancets, blood glucose meters, test strips, testing solutions, and alcohol swabs

Albumin is a protein found in the blood. Healthy kidneys stop albumin from passing into the urine. Albumin in the urine is an early sign of kidney disease. Urinary albumin levels can be affected by exercise, infection, fever, very high blood sugar, high blood pressure, heart failure, and, in women, a menstrual period. A high level should be confirmed with a follow-up test in 3 to 6 months.
--- An insulin pump and supplies (cleaning agents, batteries, plastic tubing, infusion kit, catheter, and needles) if accompanied by insulin
If you are taking tramadol, bromocriptine can lead to serious side effects.

The American College of Physicians and several studies found that any single diabetes drug except DPP-4 inhibitors lowers A1C about the same amount. DPP-4 inhibitors were not as effective. Adding any diabetes drug to metformin lowered A1C more than metformin alone. Metformin taken alone had the lowest risk of severe low blood sugar.
--- Continuous blood glucose monitors
--- Urine test strips

Avoid strenuous exercise, heavy lifting and straining, holding your breath while lifting or pushing, isometric exercises, and high-impact activity. Focus on moderate low-impact activities, such as walking, cycling, and water exercise, and moderate daily chores that do not involve heavy lifting, straining, or lowering your head below waist level.

Avoid high-impact, strenuous, or prolonged weight-bearing activity, such as long-distance walking, running on a treadmill, jumping, or hopping. Avoid exercise in heat or cold. If you have a foot injury, open sore, or ulcer, avoid all weight-bearing exercise. Focus on light-to-moderate daily activities and low-impact, moderate weight-bearing activities, such as walking, cycling, swimming, and chair exercises. Choose shoes that fit well and check your feet daily.

Avoid exercise in extreme heat and activities that require fast changes in movement. You may need an exercise stress test before you start an exercise program. Focus on mild-to-moderate aerobic activities and resistance training. Increase your exercise time slowly.

Avoid strenuous activity, heavy lifting or straining, isometric exercises, and exercising in extreme heat or cold. Focus on moderate activities, such as walking, daily chores, gardening, fishing, moderate dynamic lifting, and stretching.
Avoid strenuous activity, heavy lifting or straining, and isometric exercises. Focus on moderate activities, such as walking, weight lifting with light weights and high repetitions, and stretching.
Avoid strenuous activity. Focus on light-to-moderate daily activities, such as walking, light household chores, gardening, and water exercise.

These transplants are considered experimental and are done only on people who meet strict requirements and only in hospitals certified to do the procedure. People often need more than one transplant. After a transplant, you must take medication to suppress your immune system, so your body doesn't reject the islet cells.

There are many resources available to help you quit smoking. These include medications, nicotine replacement therapy, quit smoking programs in your workplace or community, websites, mobile phone apps, self-help materials, advice from your doctor, and motivational counseling. You may also benefit from a support group such as Nicotine Anonymous.
Avoid high-impact activity. Focus on moderate walking and non-weight-bearing exercise, such as swimming, cycling, and chair exercises.
If you are taking obinutuzumab, aspirin may not be a good option for you.

People with hyperglycemic hyperosmolar state (HHS) have very high blood glucose, usually above 600 mg/dL. Some of this glucose goes into the urine, taking water with it. People often become dehydrated. Brain function can also be affected.

Many drugs can raise or lower blood sugar and make the effects of insulin stronger or weaker. Be sure to tell your doctor about all drugs you are taking, including non-prescription drugs, before starting insulin.
Avoid high-impact activity. Focus on moderate daily activities, walking, water exercises, light lifting activities, and stretching.

If you take insulin or certain oral diabetes medications, such as sulfonylureas or glinides, you are also more likely to have low blood sugar. You may need to reduce your insulin dose before exercise or eat a snack first. If you have an insulin pump, you can reduce your basal insulin rate.
If you are taking rosiglitazone, insulin can lead to side effects and should be avoided. If you are taking pioglitazone, insulin also may not be a good option for you.
If you are taking pentosan polysulfate sodium, aspirin may not be a good option for you.

Be sure that you always have juice or glucose tabs with you in case your blood sugar drops too much. If you need to treat low blood sugar during exercise, wait until it rises above 100 mg/dL before you return to your workout.

If you are meeting your treatment goals and have stable blood glucose control, your A1C should probably be measured at least twice a year. If you are not meeting treatment goals or if your treatment has changed recently, you should probably have your A1C measured 4 times a year. If your glucose is unstable or has to be closely managed, you may need to have A1C measured more often.

Do not exercise if your blood sugar is above 240 or if you have ketones in your urine. Do not exercise right before you go to sleep. This can cause low blood sugar during the night. If your blood sugar is often too high or too low when you exercise, your doctor may need to change your meal plan or medication dosages.

The American Diabetes Association recommends moderate to vigorous physical activity for at least 2 hours and 30 minutes a week, and resistance training involving all major muscle groups 2 to 3 times a week. Time spent sitting should be reduced and broken up by intervals of activity. Older adults should engage in flexibility and balance training 2 to 3 times a week.

Gestational diabetes (diabetes that develops during pregnancy) is caused by hormones in the placenta that reduce the body's ability to use insulin. Glucose (sugar) builds up in the blood, causing diabetes. For most women, gestational diabetes does not last after childbirth. But women who have had it are more likely to have it in future pregnancies and to develop type 2 diabetes later in life.
Your doctor will need to test your liver and kidney function before starting treatment.
If you are taking another salicylate, aspirin may not be a good option for you.

People with diabetes who smoke or who are regularly exposed to secondhand smoke tend to develop diabetes complications, such as nerve and organ damage, earlier than nonsmokers. Smoking also increases the already high risk for cardiovascular disease and early death among people with diabetes.

Quitting tobacco greatly lowers your risk for many serious health problems. Your blood pressure will go down, and you will breathe easier. You will feel stronger and do better in sports and other activities. Food will taste better. Your skin, teeth, and fingernails will look healthier. You will save money. You will feel better about yourself and can stop worrying about quitting.

GLP-1 receptor agonists help the beta cells in the pancreas to release insulin. They also slow digestion and decrease appetite, and can lead to weight loss. GLP-1 receptor agonists are taken by injection under the skin using a small needle. GLP-1 receptor agonists available in the US are albiglutide (Tanzeum), dulaglutide (Trulicity), exenatide (Bydureon, Byetta), liraglutide (Victoza), lixisenatide (Adlyxin), and semaglutide (Ozempic).
If you are taking a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor, aspirin may not be a good option for you.

Insulin is a hormone produced in the pancreas. It is needed to move glucose, a source of energy, from the bloodstream into cells throughout the body. Women sometimes develop resistance to insulin during pregnancy, a condition called gestational diabetes. This is usually treated with lifestyle changes and, if needed, insulin.

Many people with diabetes have loss of feeling or poor circulation in their feet, so it is important that you pay careful attention to your feet. Unless you check your feet daily, small problems like sores and cuts can become serious before you notice them. Keeping your blood sugar under control can lower this risk. Your doctor should do a complete foot examination at least annually.

Set a time to check your feet daily. Look for red spots, changes in color or shape, cuts, swelling, blisters, or ingrown nails. Use a mirror to check the bottom of your feet if you need to. Do not open blisters, trim ingrown nails, or do anything that might break the skin. Call your doctor if you have an injury, wound, or pain, or notice anything unusual.

Wash your feet every day, after testing the water to be sure it's not too hot. Dry your feet carefully, especially between your toes. Moisturize the tops and soles of your feet with a thin coat of lotion, but do not put it between your toes. Cut your toenails straight across and smooth the edges with an emery board or nail file. Calluses and toenails can be trimmed by your doctor, if needed.

Do not use heating pads, electric blankets, or hot water bottles. Test hot water before you put your feet in it. Nerve damage can cause you to burn or damage your skin without feeling it. Put your feet up when sitting, and do not sit with your legs crossed for long stretches. Wiggle your toes and feet for 5 minutes several times a day to help with circulation. Don't smoke, which affects your circulation.

The flu vaccine protects against whatever strains of flu are present during a given flu season. Different types of vaccines are approved for different age groups. The vaccine is slightly less effective for people who have other health conditions, but it can still protect them from flu-related complications.
If you have impaired liver function, dulaglutide and liraglutide may not be good options for you.

Many women with gestational diabetes can keep their blood sugar under control with diet and exercise alone, but medication will need to be added if you can't reach your blood sugar target. Insulin is preferred. Your blood sugar will need to be monitored regularly. The goal is to reach these blood sugar targets:
--- 95 mg/dL or less before a meal
Aspirin is passed into breast milk and may not be a good option for you.
If you have multiple endocrine neoplasia syndrome type 2 (MEN-2), you should not take a GLP-1 receptor agonist.

If you have NYHA class III or IV heart failure, you should not take pioglitazone or rosiglitazone. If you have any other type of symptomatic heart failure, a glitazone may not be a good option for you.
If you are taking ibrutinib, aspirin may not be a good option for you.

Quitting smoking isn't easy. The nicotine in tobacco is an addictive drug. Up to 90% of people who smoke regularly eventually become addicted to nicotine. Knowing what to expect when you quit can help you plan ahead and manage difficult situations.
--- 140 mg/dL or less 1 hour after a meal

If you have hammertoes or bunions, or if your toes rub against the insides of your shoes, you may need extra-wide or extra-deep shoes. If you have Charcot foot or another extreme bony deformity, you may need custom-made shoes.
If you have had pancreatitis, GLP-1 receptor agonists may not be good options for you.
If you have a family history of thyroid cancer, you should not take a GLP-1 receptor agonist.
If you are taking omacetaxine, aspirin may not be a good option for you.
If you have impaired liver function, a sulfonylurea may not be a good option for you.

If you have an allergy to eggs, talk to your doctor about your allergic symptoms. Unless your allergic reaction was severe, you can still get a flu shot. To be safe, you should get the shot in a location where emergency treatment is available. An egg-free flu shot is also available. If you developed Guillain-Barre syndrome within 6 weeks of a getting a flu vaccine, talk with your doctor before getting a flu shot again.

Shingles is caused by the same virus as chickenpox. It causes a painful rash, usually on the face or body. Healthy people over the age of 50 should get the shingles vaccine, which comes in two doses 2 to 6 months apart.
If you are taking a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor, aspirin may not be a good option for you.

You should not get the shingles vaccine if you have had a severe allergic reaction to it. If you test negative for immunity to varicella zoster, you should get the chickenpox vaccine instead. Do not get the shingles vaccine if you currently have shingles or are pregnant or breastfeeding or have a fever.

A pancreas transplant is an option for some people with type 1 diabetes who have serious health problems even with insulin therapy. It may also be appropriate for people who have had a kidney transplant or are planning to have one. A new pancreas may allow you to have normal blood sugar without having to take insulin. It may also prevent, delay, or even improve complications of diabetes.

Tetanus, diphtheria, and pertussis are conditions that can be prevented with a single vaccine. Tetanus is a bacterial infection that enters the body through a cut, wound, or burn. It causes painful muscle tightening, including in the jaw. Diphtheria and pertussis are spread person to person. Symptoms of diphtheria are breathing difficulty, heart failure, or paralysis. Pertussis, or whooping cough, causes violent, uncontrolled coughing.
Aspirin can cause bleeding, ulceration, or perforation of the stomach or intestines.
Aspirin may not be a good option for you. It is not known if it is safe for pregnant women. You should not take aspirin during the last trimester of pregnancy.
If you have impaired liver function, aspirin may not be a good option for you.
If you are taking ketorolac, aspirin may not be a good option for you.

Tetanus, diphtheria, and pertussis can all result in death. In the US, children 7 or older are usually given a Tdap vaccine that combines vaccinations for the three conditions. Adults need to get a booster, or supplemental vaccine, every 10 years. Tell your doctor if you have any allergies or have had an allergic reaction to the vaccine, or if you have had Guillain-Barre syndrome or a seizure disorder.

Smoking raises a person's risk of cancer, stroke, and lung disease. Smokers have more complications from surgery. Smoking has also been linked to many other health problems, including early menopause, pregnancy complications, erection problems, osteoporosis, cataracts, gallbladder disease, rheumatoid arthritis, and tuberculosis. People exposed to secondhand smoke have many of the same health risks as smokers.

Human papillomavirus (HPV) is a sexually transmitted infection. There are many different types of HPV. It can cause genital warts and cancer, and is spread when two people have sex, even if there are no symptoms. The HPV vaccination is recommended for people between ages 11 and 26, even if they are not sexually active. People ages 27 to 45 who have not been vaccinated should ask their doctor whether the vaccine is right for them.
Lowering blood pressure by taking an ACE (angiotensin converting enzyme) inhibitor reduces the risk of heart attack, stroke, and death in people with diabetes.
--- 120 mg/dL or less 2 hours after a meal

Lifestyle choices can make a big difference in overall health and longevity. Regular exercise, a balanced and healthy diet, not smoking, and being careful when driving or traveling are important self-care strategies. Special management steps are needed during pregnancy.

Discuss the range of treatment options with your doctor. The best choices for you depend on your symptoms, whether you can maintain good glucose control, your blood pressure and cholesterol, your medical and treatment history, and to some extent, your personal preferences.
Tell your doctor if you are allergic to yeast or have had a life-threatening allergic reaction to any ingredient in the HPV vaccine. You should not get the vaccine if you are pregnant.

Pramlintide (Symlin) is a synthetic form of the hormone amylin. Pramlintide lowers blood sugar by slowing digestion and limiting glucose production by the liver. Pramlintide is taken by injection before meals. It is usually prescribed for people with type 1 or type 2 diabetes as an addition to mealtime insulin, but not commonly in the US.

Rapid-acting insulin, for use at mealtimes, is also available as an inhalant (Afrezza). Afrezza starts working in 12 to 15 minutes, peaks by 30 minutes, and stops working in about 3 hours. People with lung cancer or chronic lung disease, such as COPD or asthma, should not use inhaled insulin. Inhaled insulin is also not recommended for people who smoke or who have stopped smoking recently.
You will need to learn your own symptoms. But testing your blood glucose is the only way to confirm hypoglycemia. A blood glucose reading below 70 mg/dL is usually considered hypoglycemia.

If you are having symptoms and cannot check your blood glucose to confirm hypoglycemia, eat something to raise your blood sugar anyway. If left untreated, you could have a seizure or become unconscious. Then, someone else will have to treat you. Severe hypoglycemia can cause accidents, injuries, coma, or even death.
Some people may have symptoms of hypoglycemia even though their blood glucose is above 70 mg/dL. This may happen when blood glucose drops quickly from a very high level.

Commonly used carbohydrate and glucose rations include glucose tablets, gel tubes, 2 tablespoons of raisins, 4 ounces (1/2 cup) of juice or non-diet soda, 1 tablespoon of sugar, honey, or corn syrup, 8 ounces of nonfat or 1% milk, and hard candies, jellybeans or gumdrops.

Glucagon is a hormone that causes your liver to release glucose into your bloodstream. Glucagon is available as an injection to be given when self-treatment is not an option, such as when someone passes out or has a seizure. If you have had severe hypoglycemia, you should consider getting a prescription for glucagon kits. Your close contacts or caregivers will need to be trained how to use the kits.

Some people feel no symptoms when they have hypoglycemia. This is called hypoglycemia unawareness. It typically happens in people who have had diabetes for a long time, frequently have low blood sugar, or tightly control their blood sugar.

People with hypoglycemia unawareness are likely to allow hypoglycemia to go untreated, because they don't know it's happening. This can be dangerous. If you have hypoglycemia unawareness, your doctor may need to relax your blood glucose targets and reduce the dosages of your diabetes medications.

People with diabetes have a higher risk of serious gum disease. Diabetes makes it harder for your body to fight bacteria and fungal infections, and poor blood sugar control can make this problem even worse. In turn, gum disease can make it harder to control your blood sugar. Good oral hygiene and blood sugar control will help you avoid gum disease and improve your overall health.
--- red, swollen, or tender gums
--- bleeding gums when you brush or floss
--- pus that comes out when you press on your gums
--- receding gums (gums that have pulled away from the teeth)
--- loose or moving teeth
--- bad breath
--- changes in your bite or in the fit of dentures or bridges

You will need to take medication to suppress your immune system for the rest of your life. This is to keep your body from rejecting the transplanted tissue. But it also lowers your resistance to infections and cancer.

Gingivitis is gum disease. Periodontitis is severe gum disease. People with diabetes are at greater risk of gingivitis and periodontitis. Treatment of periodontitis can improve your diabetes and your A1C levels.
--- Strengthen your muscles with weight-training, resistance bands, push-ups, pull-ups, or sit-ups.
--- Preeclampsia (high blood pressure and protein in your urine)
--- Difficult delivery or cesarean section
If your blood sugar is too high during pregnancy, your baby is at risk for these problems:
--- Premature delivery or miscarriage
--- Birth defects
--- Macrosomia (a large baby)
--- Low blood sugar, jaundice (yellow skin), and breathing problems at birth

The ideal blood sugar levels when you are planning to get pregnant may be different than you are used to. You should discuss your best target numbers with your healthcare provider. These numbers will also be different than the levels that are considered acceptable for a pregnant woman. Those are:
If your blood sugar is too high during pregnancy, you are at risk for these problems:
--- less than 95 mg/dL before meals
--- 100 to 140 mg/dL 1 hour after meals

Not getting enough insulin can cause life-threatening emergencies. One of these is diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), which is more common in people with type 1 diabetes. Another is hyperglycemic hyperosmolar state (HHS), which is more common in people with type 2 diabetes. These conditions can be caused by skipping or forgetting doses of insulin or by stress on the body caused by a severe illness, such as an infection.
You should also try to reach an A1C of 6.5% or less, reach and maintain a healthy weight, watch your diet, and exercise.

Before getting pregnant, see your doctor for a complete checkup. This will include an A1C test and exams to check for blood pressure, heart, kidney, eye, or nerve problems. If you have type 1 diabetes, you should also have a thyroid test. Your doctor will review your medications. Some medications may need to be stopped during pregnancy. This may include drugs you take for diabetes and its complications.
Be sure to use a reliable birth control method until your blood sugar is under control.
If you have unstable heart failure, you should not take metformin. Once your heart failure is stable, metformin can be taken as long as kidney function is normal.
If you have impaired liver function, bromocriptine may not be a good option for you.
Your doctor may recommend a stress test before starting an exercise program.
Your doctor may also talk to you about your diet, supplements, immunizations, and any genetic tests that you may need.
If you have gastropathy, GLP-1 agonists can lead to side effects and should be avoided.

For many people, symptoms such as sweating, chills, and shakiness occur earlier in the hypoglycemic episode. These can serve as a warning to address the hypoglycemia before it worsens. Some later symptoms, such as confusion or fatigue, can make it harder to recognize the problem and respond to it.
If you are taking an alpha-glucosidase inhibitor (acarbose or miglitol), take oral glucose (dextrose), not sucrose (cane sugar), to correct hypoglycemia.

Side effects may include fatigue, weakness, headaches, dizziness, fainting, cough, swelling, muscle pain, skin rash, nausea, and diarrhea. Some people have a drop in blood pressure that is greater than expected.
You should not take an ACE inhibitor if you are breastfeeding.

SGLT2 inhibitors may not be recommended for people with peripheral vascular disease, neuropathy, or diabetic foot ulcers. Some people who took the SGLT2 inhibitor canagliflozin required amputation of a toe, foot, or leg. While the risk is very low, these medical conditions may increase that risk. Anyone taking an SGLT2 inhibitor should have regular foot care and monitor for pain and skin changes often.

There are many types of drugs that lower blood sugar in people with type 2 diabetes. They work in different ways. Sulfonylureas and gliptins raise your natural insulin levels. Metformin and glitazones help your body use its own insulin better. They also reduce the release of glucose from your liver. GLP-1 receptor agonists slow carbohydrate digestion. SGLT2 inhibitors stop your kidneys from reabsorbing glucose.
If you are taking aliskiren, ACE inhibitors can lead to side effects and should be avoided.

Side effects may include nausea, headaches, loss of appetite, vomiting, abdominal pain, fatigue, dizziness, cough, and sore throat. Pramlintide increases the risk of severe hypoglycemia (low blood sugar), usually within 3 hours of injection.
You should not take a GLP-1 receptor agonist if you are breastfeeding.
Pramlintide increases the risk of severe hypoglycemia. This is especially dangerous for people who are unaware of hypoglycemia symptoms.
If you have impaired kidney function, GLP-1 agonists may not be good options for you. Exenatide should not be taken by people with severe kidney impairment or end-stage renal disease.
You should not take Saxenda (the form of liraglutide used to treat obesity) if you are pregnant. It is not known if other GLP-1 receptor agonists are safe for pregnant women.

There is no single diet recommended for people with diabetes. There is also no exact percentage of calories you should be getting from carbohydrates, protein, and fat. But the Mediterranean-style diet, low carbohydrate diets, and plant-based diets have all shown positive benefits for people with diabetes. Your total calories should be based on your weight or weight goal.

Blood pressure targets for all adults with diabetes are a systolic pressure (upper number) below 140 and a diastolic pressure (lower number) below 90. Lower targets may be recommended for people with risk factors for cardiovascular disease. The American Diabetes Association recommends home monitoring of blood pressure for people with diabetes and high blood pressure.

Part or all of a pancreas from a donor is transplanted into your body. Your old pancreas is left in place. It will still make the enzymes used for digestion, even though it is not making insulin. A pancreas transplant is major surgery and has many risks.
--- Bladder and vaginal infections
Women with gestational diabetes should aim for a blood glucose of 95 mg/dL or below before meals and 140 mg/dL or below one hour after meals or 120 mg/dL two hours after meals.

Glitazones lower blood glucose by improving the body's ability to respond to insulin. They also limit the conversion of starch to glucose in the liver. Glitazones available in the US include pioglitazone (Actos) and rosiglitazone (Avandia). Glitazones are taken by mouth. They may be prescribed alone or in combination with other diabetes drugs. Several products are available that combine a glitazone in a single pill with another diabetes drug, such as metformin.
You should not take a glitazone if you are breastfeeding.
If you are breastfeeding, pramlintide may not be a good option for you. It is not known if this drug can be passed into breast milk.
People taking aspirin should avoid receiving live or attenuated chickenpox or flu vaccines.

Without insulin, your cells cannot get the glucose they need for energy. They burn fat for energy instead. This releases chemicals called ketones which makes the blood more acidic. High levels of ketones can lead to serious complications, a diabetic coma, or even death.

Some people with diabetes can benefit from taking low-dose aspirin (75 to 162 mg a day). This includes people with cardiovascular disease or a higher risk of it. The risk is higher in people over age 50 with diabetes and at least 1 other major risk factor for cardiovascular disease. Major risk factors include high blood pressure, high cholesterol, too much protein in the urine, smoking, or a family history of cardiovascular disease.

Planning ahead for pregnancy is critically important for your baby's health and your own. You need to get your blood sugar in control before you get pregnant, ideally 3 to 6 months before. In many cases, by the time you realize you're pregnant, the fetal organs have already formed. High blood sugar, especially in the first 7 weeks of pregnancy, will put you and your developing baby at risk for complications.
If you are breastfeeding, you should not take a sulfonylurea.
If you have impaired kidney function, a sulfonylurea may not be a good option for you.

Side effects may include fluid retention, weight gain, increased liver enzymes, hepatitis, and liver failure. Other side effects may include headaches, fatigue, diarrhea, sinus and upper respiratory tract infections, muscle and back pain, bone loss, and fractures. Glitazones can cause or worsen heart failure. Rosiglitazone may cause a return of ovulation in women who have not been ovulating. This may increase the chances of pregnancy.
Pramlintide may not be a good option for you. It is not known if it is safe for pregnant women.

Insulin injections can cause an allergic reaction, such as itching, swelling, redness, stinging, or warmth at the site of the injection. These reactions usually occur in the first three weeks after beginning injections and disappear within a few days or weeks.
If you have kidney impairment, you should not take an alpha-glucosidase inhibitor.
If you have cirrhosis of the liver, you should not take acarbose.
Alpha-glucosidase inhibitors may not be a good option for you. It is not known if they are safe for pregnant women.

Exercise can lower your blood sugar by improving your body's response to insulin. If you exercise regularly, your doctor may be able to reduce your diabetes medications. Exercise can also lower your risk of heart and blood vessel disease, brighten your mood, and improve your quality of life.

If you are overweight begin your dietary changes with efforts to lose weight. The Mediterranean diet or the Dietary Approaches to Stop Hypertension (DASH diet) are good choices for people with diabetes. Limit the amount of saturated fats and trans fats. This is especially important if you have high LDL cholesterol. Choose foods that are high in fiber and omega-3 fatty acids to further lower your risk of heart and blood vessel disease.

High-intensity statin therapy is recommended for everyone that has both diabetes and cardiovascular disease. Statins may be recommended for other adults with diabetes even if they don't have cardiovascular disease. However, statins should not be taken by pregnant women. Ezetimibe or PCSK9 inhibitors may be added to a statin for some adults at high risk for heart disease or who cannot tolerate high statin doses.

Insulin, a hormone that helps keep blood sugar under control, is usually produced by islet cells in the pancreas. But in people with type 1 diabetes, the islet cells do not make enough insulin. Some people with type 1 diabetes can control their blood sugar with medication. If that does not work, an islet cell transplant may be an option. During a transplant, islet cells are taken from a donor pancreas, purified, and placed in the liver of the person with diabetes.

Eat 15 to 20 grams of glucose or simple carbohydrates, a very small banana or a couple of rice cakes, for example. After 15 minutes, recheck your blood glucose. If you are still hypoglycemic, eat another 15 to 20 grams. When your blood glucose gets back to normal, eat a small snack if your next planned meal is more than an hour away.

If you have moderate to severe liver disease, you should not take pioglitazone. If you have mild liver disease, pioglitazone may not be a good option for you. Rosiglitazone may cause elevated liver enzymes, hepatitis, and liver failure.
