If you are breastfeeding, metformin may not be a good option for you. It is not known if this drug can be is passed into breast milk.
Glinides may not be a good option for you. It is not known if they are safe for pregnant women.

Side effects may include vomiting, diarrhea, gas, indigestion, and abdominal bloating or cramping. Other side effects may include headaches, a low vitamin B12 level, and low blood sugar. Lactic acidosis, an uncommon but serious condition involving excess lactic acid in the blood, may occur. This is more common in people with kidney disease.
If you are taking a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug, an ACE inhibitor may not be a good option for you.
You should not take a glinide if you are breastfeeding.
Side effects may include headaches, dizziness, flu-like symptoms, upper respiratory infections, joint pain, back pain, fatigue, diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, and constipation.

People with diabetes should have a blood pressure goal of 140/90 or less. Lower targets may be recommended for people with risk factors for cardiovascular disease. ARBs (angiotensin receptor blockers) and ACE inhibitors (angiotensin-converting-enzyme inhibitors) are the preferred medications for high blood pressure because they reduce the risk of cardiovascular disease as well as the progress of kidney disease.

A1C, or glycosylated hemoglobin, is used to estimate glucose control over several months. The higher your A1C value, the greater the likelihood that you will develop complications from diabetes, such as blood vessel, nerve, or organ damage.
Glitazones may not be a good option for you. It is not known if they are safe for pregnant women.
Women with type 1 or 2 diabetes who become pregnant should aim for a blood glucose of 95 mg/dL or below before meals and 140 mg/dL or below one hour after meals or 120 mg/dL two hours after meals.

People with type 2 diabetes should have an initial dilated and comprehensive eye exam by an ophthalmologist or optometrist at the time diabetes is diagnosed. If there are no problems, exams should be repeated at least every 1 to 2 years. If any exam reveals a problem, exams should be repeated at least yearly. If a problem is severe or getting worse, exams should be more frequent.

Regardless of treatment type, glucose goals for all non-pregnant adults with diabetes using self-monitoring devices are a fasting (before-meal) plasma glucose of 80 to 130 mg/dL and an after-meal plasma glucose below 180 mg/dL. Take your after-meal glucose measurements 1 to 2 hours after the beginning of the meal.

Your doctor may compare blood pressure in your arm with blood pressure in your leg to check for signs of blockage in your leg arteries, which can lead to foot problems. This test is called the ankle-brachial index. Your doctor may recommend it if you have symptoms of blockage, such as leg fatigue, calf pain, or slow walking speed. The test may also be recommended if you are over 50, smoke, have high blood pressure or cholesterol, or have had diabetes for over 10 years.
You may also want to carry a TSA (Transportation Security Administration) Disability Notification Card.
--- Do not leave medications in the glove compartment or trunk, or near a window where they might overheat.
--- Stay comfortable and reduce your risk for blood clots by moving around every 1 to 2 hours.
--- Wear comfortable shoes. Never go barefoot, even when swimming. Check your feet every day for blisters, cuts, redness, swelling, and scratches.
--- Carry a first aid kit with you, stocked with items for treating minor illnesses, cuts, scratches, and other first aid needs.
--- Check your blood glucose often. Changes in diet, activity, and time zones can affect blood sugar in unexpected ways.

It is important to maintain your usual self-care routine, whether at home or away. When you travel, be alert to special situations that may raise your risk for a problem or complication. Diabetes can make you more prone to infections when you travel. Here are some more tips:

In foreign countries, insulin comes in different strengths. If you purchase insulin in a foreign country, be sure to use the right syringe for the strength you buy. The wrong syringe may cause you to take too much insulin, or not enough.
Always tell the flight attendant that you have diabetes, especially if you are traveling alone.

Ask your doctor for a letter written on office letterhead stating that you have diabetes, listing your medications and supplies (especially syringes), and explaining why you need them. Take along a prescription for insulin or other diabetes medications, in case of an emergency.

If food is served on your flight, call ahead to order a diabetic, low-fat, or low-cholesterol meal. Wait until the food is about to be served before taking insulin. A delay in the meal could lead to low blood sugar. If no food is offered, bring a meal with you.

Diabetes medications and supplies need to be screened by x-ray or inspected by hand at the security checkpoint. You should declare these items and keep them separate from other belongings. Prescription labels are not required, but they will speed up inspection. Pack your medications in clear re-sealable bags.

If you use insulin, keep it cool by packing it in an insulated bag with refrigerated gel packs. High or low temperatures and pressure can affect insulin, so do not pack it in checked baggage. Also, pack a glucagon emergency kit.
Pack twice the amount of diabetes medication and supplies that you would normally need. Keep snacks, glucose gel, or glucose tablets with you, in case your blood sugar drops.

Plan ahead for time zone changes. Be sure you know when to take your diabetes medication, no matter where you are. Eastward travel means a shorter day, so you may need less insulin than usual. Westward travel means a longer day, so you may need more insulin.

Carry medical identification that says you have diabetes. For example, get an ID bracelet or necklace, and put diabetes ID cards in your wallet. The identification should be written in the languages of the places you are visiting. Make sure at least one person traveling with you knows about your diabetes.
See your doctor for a checkup 4 to 6 weeks before your trip to make sure your ABCs (A1C, blood pressure, and cholesterol) are under control and in a healthy range.

With some planning, you can safely manage your diabetes while traveling. Depending on your travel plans, you will need to carry extra supplies, keep medications and supplies handy, store insulin properly, comply with air travel rules, and know what to do in foreign countries. You will also need to maintain your usual self-care routine while you're away.

Metformin (Fortamet, Glucophage, Glumetza, Riomet) lowers blood glucose by decreasing the production of glucose in the liver. Metformin is taken by mouth. It may be prescribed alone or in combination with other diabetes drugs. Many products are available that combine metformin with other diabetes drugs in a single pill. Because it is effective, relatively safe, low cost, and has heart-health benefits, metformin is usually the first drug prescribed for type 2 diabetes.

Long-acting insulins include detemir (Levemir), degludec (Tresiba), and glargine (Lantus, Basaglar). They start working in several hours. They have no peak, and their effects last for about 24 hours. An ultra long-acting insulin glargine u-300 (Toujeo) reaches the blood stream in six hours and lasts 36 hours or longer.

Alpha-glucosidase inhibitors slow the digestion of carbohydrates in the small intestine. This can lead to lowering of A1c levels by a small amount. Alpha-glucosidase inhibitors available in the US include acarbose (Precose) and miglitol (Glyset). These drugs are taken by mouth. They are most often prescribed in combination with other diabetes drugs.
Sulfonylureas may not be good options for you. It is not known if they are safe for pregnant women.
Side effects may include nausea, a feeling of stomach fullness, abdominal discomfort, heartburn, gas, allergic skin reactions, and weight gain.

Sulfonylureas lower blood glucose by stimulating beta cells in the pancreas to release insulin. Sulfonylureas are taken by mouth. They may be prescribed alone or in combination with other diabetes drugs.
--- Vary your routine. Don't let boredom slow your progress.

Lifestyle changes are recommended for all people with diabetes whose blood pressure is higher than 120/80. This includes weight loss if overweight, reducing sodium and increasing potassium in the diet, limiting alcohol intake, and getting more physical activity. Drug therapy is recommended for anyone with blood pressure of 140/90 or higher.

Check your blood sugar before, during, and after exercise, at least until you know how it is affected by an activity. Some activities may lower your blood sugar quickly. In general, the longer and harder you exercise, the greater your risk of low blood sugar.
